snippet: Emboldened by the fall of Saddam Hussein, Iraqi women are pushing for political freedoms many of them have never enjoyed. But as they do, a rising tide of religious zeal threatens even the small victories they have won.     Ibtisam Ali and her sis...
lead_paragraph: Emboldened by the fall of Saddam Hussein, Iraqi women are pushing for political freedoms many of them have never enjoyed. But as they do, a rising tide of religious zeal threatens even the small victories they have won. Ibtisam Ali and her sister, Raghad, have spearheaded a petition drive demanding a large percentage of seats for women in a new national assembly. But when Raghad, 25, tried to run for local office, the men at the candidate registration office informed her that women could not be candidates.
abstract: Iraqi women, emboldened by fall of Saddam Hussein, are pushing for political freedoms many of them have never enjoyed, even as rising tide of religious zeal threatens even small victories they have won; intimidation of woman who tried to run for local office described; committee drafting new constitution does not include any women and has called for Islamic law on family matters, while on streets many women are covering heads and bodies for fear of harassment; photo (M)

headline.main: Iraqi Women's Window of Opportunity for Political Gains Is Closing

snippet: When a Kenyan woman loses her husband, she also frequently loses her home, her land, her cows and all her other household property. What the widow gains, whether she likes it or not, is a new husband, frequently her brother-in-law.    Human Rights...
lead_paragraph: When a Kenyan woman loses her husband, she also frequently loses her home, her land, her cows and all her other household property. What the widow gains, whether she likes it or not, is a new husband, frequently her brother-in-law. Human Rights Watch issued a report today condemning the traditional African practice of wife inheritance, in which a widow is transferred to a male relative of her deceased husband. Typically the new husband takes control of the property with or without the consent of the widow.
abstract: Human Rights Watch issues report condemning traditional African practice of wife inheritance, in which widow is transferred to male relative of deceased husband who typically takes control of property with or without her consent; custom extends across sub-Saharan Africa; its practice in Kenya discussed; traditional elders say it ensures that extended family will take care of widows, but critics maintain it strips women of their property rights and exposes them to sexually transmitted diseases such as AIDS (M)

headline.main: Rights Group Calls for End To Inheriting African Wives

snippet: The past haunts farmers in this village, set high in the mountains that rise over Mexico's Pacific Coast.    The corn was close to harvest, they remember, in September 1972, when soldiers surrounded their fields one afternoon and summoned all male...
lead_paragraph: The past haunts farmers in this village, set high in the mountains that rise over Mexico's Pacific Coast. The corn was close to harvest, they remember, in September 1972, when soldiers surrounded their fields one afternoon and summoned all male residents above the age of 16 to a meeting on the concrete basketball court at the center of the village. About 95 men and boys lined up, as soldiers took down their names, ages and the number of hectares of land each owned. Then the farmers were herded into a one-room house that had been used as an elementary school. And their lives went dark.
abstract: Residents of village of El Quemado, Mex, are haunted by memories of what happened in Sept, 1972, when soldiers surounded their fields and summoned all male residents and accused them of having helped guerrillas stage ambush that left several soldiers dead; men were tortured and close to 50 of them were convicted of treason and sentenced to jail; 7 of them were never seen again; Pres Vicente Fox had promised to investigate this and other heinous atrocities, but Human Rights Watch has faulted him for not putting his full authority behind that effort; photos; map (M)

headline.main: El Quemado Journal; A Mexican Village Mourns Its Abducted Sons

snippet: A new show at the South Street Seaport features the preserved remains of 22 people and 260 other specimens....
lead_paragraph: The jaunty fellow with the conductor's baton waving in one hand stands on a pedestal seemingly lost in the music. But there are a few startlingly odd things about this tall, lithe gentleman: He is dead, his skin has been methodically ripped away and there is a pinkish void where his viscera are supposed to be. Besides a few supporting segments of muscle, bone and ligament, the man has been rendered into a web of white spindly nerves. It is impossible to know what he did in life, but in death the man has become a ghoulish show-and-tell exemplar of the human nervous system, part of a new exhibit that opens tomorrow at the South Street Seaport. The show, called ''Bodies . . . the Exhibition,'' features the preserved remains of 22 people and 260 other specimens, including a set of conjoined fetuses, a set of male genitalia, a pudgy woman who has been vertically sliced into four equal segments and a sprinter whose flayed muscles fly around him like slices of prosciutto.

headline.main: Cadaver Exhibition Raises Questions Beyond Taste

snippet: As many as one in five of the 2.1 million Americans in jail and prison are seriously mentally ill, far outnumbering the number of mentally ill who are in mental hospitals, according to a comprehensive study released Tuesday.    The study, by Human...
lead_paragraph: As many as one in five of the 2.1 million Americans in jail and prison are seriously mentally ill, far outnumbering the number of mentally ill who are in mental hospitals, according to a comprehensive study released Tuesday. The study, by Human Rights Watch, concludes that jails and prisons have become the nation's default mental health system, as more state hospitals have closed and as the country's prison system has quadrupled over the past 30 years. There are now fewer than 80,000 people in mental hospitals, and the number is continuing to fall.
abstract: Human Rights Watch study finds that as many as one in five of 2.1 million American prison inmates are seriously mentally ill, and that prison system has become default mental health system (M)

headline.main: Study Finds Hundreds of Thousands of Inmates Mentally Ill

snippet: An international human rights group accused the Russian military of conducting a deliberate campaign of murder among Chechen civilians, killing between 50 and 80 people a month. The International Helsinki Federation for Human Rights said Russian f...
lead_paragraph: An international human rights group accused the Russian military of conducting a deliberate campaign of murder among Chechen civilians, killing between 50 and 80 people a month. The International Helsinki Federation for Human Rights said Russian forces attack young Chechen men in what appears to be a process of reducing the male population, a charge a Russian official vigorously denied. The killings are claiming more lives than Russian bombing in previous military campaigns against separatist rebels in the republic, the group said. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)
abstract: International Helsinki Federation for Human Rights charges Russian military conducts deliberate campaign of murder among Chechen civilians, killing between 50 and 80 people a month; says drive seems aimed at young men (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Accusation Of Murder In Chechnya
